Nakipagnegosasyon ang California sa pederal na pamahalaan para malimitahan sa impormasyon lang na hindi magbibigay ng pagkakakilanlan ng indibidwal ang kinakailangang pagbabahagi ng data.

Magbasa pa sa [Kasunduan sa Paggamit ng Data ng California at Mga Madalas Itanong](https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/Pages/COVID-19/California-Data-Use-Agreement.aspx) ng CDPH.

More info: [Mga Bakuna](https://covid19.ca.gov/tl/vaccines/)

Question: Mayroon akong mga allergy. Dapat ba akong magpabakuna laban sa COVID-19?
Answer:
Depende. [Inirerekomenda ng CDC](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/safety/allergic-reaction.html) na:

*   Kung nagkaroon ka ng matinding allergic na reaksyon o agarang allergic na reaksyon—kahit hindi ito malala—sa anumang sangkap sa isang bakuna para sa COVID-19 na mula sa mRNA, hindi mo dapat kunin ang alinman sa mga bakuna para sa COVID-19 na mula sa mRNA na available sa kasalukuyan (Pfizer-BioNTech at Moderna).
*   Kung nagkaroon ka ng matinding allergic na reaksyon o agarang allergic na reaksyon sa anumang sangkap sa bakuna laban sa COVID-19 ng Johnson & Johnson’s Janssen, hindi ka dapat magpabakuna ng bakuna ng J&J/Janssen.
*   Kung nagkaroon ka ng agarang allergic na reaksyon pagkatapos ng unang dosis ng isang bakuna para sa COVID-19 na mula sa mRNA, hindi mo dapat kunin ang pangalawang dosis.  
*   Kung may allergy ka sa PEG, hindi ka dapat magpaturok ng bakuna laban sa COVID-19 ng mRNA. Tanungin ang iyong doktor kung puwede kang magpaturok ng bakuna ng Janssen.
*   Kung may allergy ka sa polysorbate, hindi dapat magpaturok ng bakuna ng Janssen. Tanungin ang iyong doktor kung puwede kang magpaturok ng bakuna laban sa COVID-19 ng mRNA.
*   Kung hindi ka makakapagpaturok ng isang uri ng bakuna laban sa COVID-19 dahil allergic ka sa isang sangkap sa bakunang iyon, tanungin ang iyong doktor kung dapat kang kumuha ng ibang uri ng bakuna kaban sa COVID-19. 
*   Kung hindi ka makakuha ang ikalawang turok ng bakuna ng mRNA dahil nagkaroon ka ng allergic na reaksyon sa unang turok, tanungin ang iyong doktor kung dapat kang kumuha ng ibang uri ng bakuna laban sa COVID-19. 
*   Kung nagkaroon ka na ng malalang allergic na reaksyon sa iba pang bakuna o iniksyon, dapat mong tanungin ang iyong doktor kung dapat kang magpabakuna laban sa COVID-19.
*   Ang mga taong dati nang nagkaroon ng mga malalang allergic na reaksyon na hindi nauugnay sa mga bakuna o iniksyon ay puwede pa ring magpabakuna. Puwedeng magbakuna ang mga tao kahit:
    *   Dati na silang nagkaroon ng allergy sa mga iniinom na gamot
    *   Dati nang nagkaroon ang kanilang mga kapamilya ng mga malalang allergic na reaksyon
    *   Mayroon silang hindi masyadong malalang allergy sa mga bakuna

More info: [Mga Bakuna](https://covid19.ca.gov/tl/vaccines/)

Question: Ano ang mga sangkap ng bakuna laban sa COVID-19?
Answer:
Kasama sa mga sangkap ng bakuna ng Pfizer-BioNTech at Moderna ang:

*   mRNA
*   Mga lipid
*   Mga salt
*   Mga sugar
*   Mga buffer 

Tumutulong ang mga buffer na panatilihin ang stability ng pH solution. 

Kasama sa bakuna ng Janssen ang mga sumusunod na sangkap: 

*   Recombinant na replication-incompetent na adenovirus type 26, na nag-e-express sa SARS-CoV-2 spike protein
*   Citric acid monohydrate
*   Trisodium citrate dihydrate
*   Ethanol
*   2-hydroxypropyl-β-cyclodextrin (HBCD), polysorbate-80
*   Sodium chloride

Ang mga bakunang ito ay walang:

*   Itlog
*   Preservative
*   Latex

Para matuto pa tungkol sa mga sangkap sa mga awtorisadong bakuna laban sa COVID-19, tingnan ang

*   [Impormasyon tungkol sa bakuna laban sa COVID-19 ng Pfizer-BioNTech](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/different-vaccines/Pfizer-BioNTech.html)
*   [Impormasyon tungkol sa bakuna laban sa COVID-19 ng Moderna](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/different-vaccines/Moderna.html)
*   [Impormasyon Tungkol sa Bakuna Laban sa COVID-19 ng Johnson & Johnson’s Janssen](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/different-vaccines/janssen.html)

More info: [Mga Bakuna](https://covid19.ca.gov/tl/vaccines/)

Question: Mayroon bang ilang partikular na populasyon na hindi dapat magpabakuna para sa COVID-19?
Answer:
[Inirerekomenda ng CDC](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/safety/allergic-reaction.html) na:

*   Kung nagkaroon ka ng matinding allergic na reaksyon o agarang allergic na reaksyon—kahit hindi ito malala—sa anumang sangkap sa isang bakuna para sa COVID-19 na mula sa mRNA, hindi mo dapat kunin ang alinman sa mga bakuna para sa COVID-19 na mula sa mRNA na available sa kasalukuyan (Pfizer-BioNTech at Moderna).
*   Kung nagkaroon ka ng matinding allergic na reaksyon o agarang allergic na reaksyon sa anumang sangkap sa bakuna laban sa COVID-19 ng Johnson & Johnson’s Janssen, hindi ka dapat magpabakuna ng bakuna ng J&J/Janssen.
*   Kung nagkaroon ka ng agarang allergic na reaksyon pagkatapos ng unang dosis ng isang bakuna para sa COVID-19 na mula sa mRNA, hindi mo dapat kunin ang pangalawang dosis.  
*   Kung may allergy ka sa PEG, hindi ka dapat magpaturok ng bakuna laban sa COVID-19 ng mRNA. Tanungin ang iyong doktor kung puwede kang magpaturok ng bakuna ng Janssen.
*   Kung may allergy ka sa polysorbate, hindi dapat magpaturok ng bakuna ng Janssen. Tanungin ang iyong doktor kung puwede kang magpaturok ng bakuna laban sa COVID-19 ng mRNA.
*   Kung hindi ka makakapagpaturok ng isang uri ng bakuna laban sa COVID-19 dahil allergic ka sa isang sangkap sa bakunang iyon, tanungin ang iyong doktor kung dapat kang kumuha ng ibang uri ng bakuna kaban sa COVID-19. 
*   Kung hindi ka makakuha ang ikalawang turok ng bakuna ng mRNA dahil nagkaroon ka ng allergic na reaksyon sa unang turok, tanungin ang iyong doktor kung dapat kang kumuha ng ibang uri ng bakuna laban sa COVID-19.

Ang mga taong may mga dati nang medikal na kundisyon ay puwedeng makatanggap ng mga bakuna laban sa COVID-19 na naaprubahan ng FDA basta't hindi pa sila nagkakaroon ng [agaran o matinding allergic na reaksyon](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/safety/allergic-reaction.html) sa isang bakuna laban sa COVID-19 o sa anumang sangkap sa bakuna. Matuto pa tungkol sa mga pagsasaalang-alang sa pagbabakuna [para sa mga taong may mga dati nang medikal na kundisyon.](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/recommendations/underlying-conditions.html) Mahalagang pag-isipang magpabakuna ng mga nasa hustong gulang, anuman ang kanilang edad, na may ilang partikular na dati nang medikal na kundisyon dahil mas malaki ang posibilidad nilang magkasakit dahil sa virus na nagdudulot ng COVID-19.

More info: [Mga Bakuna](https://covid19.ca.gov/tl/vaccines/)

Question: Puwede bang magpabakuna laban sa COVID-19 ang mga buntis o nagpapasuso na kababaihan?
Answer:
Oo. [Inirerekomenda ng CDC](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/recommendations/pregnancy.html) na kung buntis ka, puwede mong piliin na mabakunahan kapag available na ito para sa iyo. Sa kasalukuyan ay walang patunay na nagdudulot ng anumang problema sa pagbubuntis, kasama ang pagkakabuo ng placenta, ang mga antibody na nabubuo mula sa pagpapabakuna laban sa COVID-19.

Ang mga taong sumusubok na mabuntis ngayon o may planong sumubok sa hinaharap ay puwede ring tumanggap ng bakuna laban sa COVID-19 kapag naging available ito para sa kanila. Walang patunay na side effect ng anumang bakuna ang mga problema sa fertility, kasama ang mga bakuna laban sa COVID-19. Walang routine na rekomendasyon sa pagkuha ng pagsusuri sa pagbubuntis bago ka magpabakuna laban sa COVID-19. Kung mayroon kang mga tanong tungkol sa pagpapabakuna, makipag-usap sa isang provider sa pangangalagang pangkalusugan para tulungan kang makapagpasya nang may batayan.

More info: [Mga Bakuna](https://covid19.ca.gov/tl/vaccines/)

Question: Gaano katagal ako dapat maghintay bago ko kunin ang bakuna pagkatapos kong magkaroon ng COVID-19?
Answer:
Inirerekomenda ng [CDC ang sumusunod:](https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/covid-19/info-by-product/clinical-considerations.html?CDC_AA_refVal=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.cdc.gov%2Fvaccines%2Fcovid-19%2Finfo-by-product%2Fpfizer%2Fclinical-considerations.html)

*   Kung nagpositibo ka sa pagsusuri, hindi malala ang iyong mga naging sintomas, at hindi ka ginamot para sa coronavirus, dapat kang maghintay sa loob ng kahit man lang 10 araw mula sa simula ng mga sintomas ng COVID-19 **at** matugunan ang [mga pamantayan](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/hcp/disposition-in-home-patients.html) para sa paghinto sa pag-isolate bago mo kunin ang bakuna para sa COVID-19.
*   Maghintay ng 90 araw bago kunin ang bakuna kung gumaling ka mula sa COVID-19 at ginamot ka gamit ang mga monoclonal antibody o convalescent plasma.

More info: [Mga Bakuna](https://covid19.ca.gov/tl/vaccines/)

Question: Puwede ko bang kunin ang bakuna para sa COVID-19 kasabay ng ibang bakuna?
Answer:
Inirerekomenda ng [CDC ang sumusunod:](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/faq.html#)

*   Maghintay ng hindi bababa sa 14 araw bago ka kumuha ng iba pang bakuna, kasama ang bakuna para sa trangkaso o shingles, kung uunahin mong kunin ang iyong bakuna para sa COVID-19. At kung ibang bakuna ang uunahin mo, maghintay ng hindi bababa sa 14 na araw bago mo kunin ang iyong bakuna para sa COVID-19.
*   Kung hindi sinasadyang maibibigay ang bakuna para sa COVID-19 wala pang 14 na araw pagkatapos ng ibang bakuna, hindi mo kailangang simulan ulit ang serye ng bakuna para sa COVID-19; dapat mo pa ring kumpletuhin ang serye ayon sa iskedyul. Kapag mas marami nang available na data tungkol sa kaligtasan at bisa ng mga bakuna para sa COVID-19 kapag ibinigay kasabay ng iba pang bakuna, posibleng i-update ng CDC ang rekomendasyong ito.

More info: [Mga Bakuna](https://covid19.ca.gov/tl/vaccines/)

Question: Ligtas ba para sa mga bata ang bakuna para sa COVID-19?
Answer:
Sa kasalukuyan, hindi inirerekomenda ang COVID-19 para sa mga bata:

*   Ang bakuna ng Pfizer/BioNTech ay para sa mga labing-anim na taong gulang pataas
*   Ang bakuna ng Moderna ay para sa mga labingwalong taong gulang pataas
*   Ang bakuna ng Johnson & Johnson ay para sa mga may edad na labingwalong gulang pataas

Patuloy ang mga klinikal na pagsubok para matukoy ang ligtas na bakuna para sa mga bata.

More info: [Mga Bakuna](https://covid19.ca.gov/tl/vaccines/)

Question: Puwede ba akong pumili sa pagitan ng iba't ibang bakuna laban sa COVID-19?
Answer: Depende. Alamin sa iyong provider sa pangangalagang pangkalusugan kung anong bakuna ang available sa kanila.\n\nMore info: [Mga Bakuna](https://covid19.ca.gov/tl/vaccines/)

Question: Mandatoryo ba ang mga bakuna para sa COVID-19?
Answer: Hindi, walang mandatoryong kinakailangan sa pagpababakuna mula sa pamahalaan ng estado o pederal.  Kapag mas marami pang Californian ang nakaalam kung gaano kaligtas at kabisa ang mga bakuna para sa COVID-19, umaasa kaming boluntaryo silang magpapabakuna para dito.\n\nMore info: [Mga Bakuna](https://covid19.ca.gov/tl/vaccines/)

Question: Puwede bang gawing mandatoryo ng isang employer ang pagpapabakuna sa isang lugar ng trabaho?
Answer:
Oo. Puwedeng atasan ng isang employer ang mga empleyadong tumanggap ng bakunang naaprubahan ng Pangasiwaan ng Pagkain at Gamot (Food and Drug Administration, FDA) laban sa pagkahawa ng COVID-19 basta't ang employer ay:

*   Hindi mandidiskrimina o manliligalig ng mga empleyado o aplikante sa trabaho batay sa mga pinoprotektahang katangian
*   Magbibigay ng mga makatuwirang akomodasyon na nauugnay sa kapansanan o isinasabuhay na paniniwala o kagawian sa pananampalataya
*   Hindi maghihiganti sa sinumang makikibahagi sa mga pinoprotektahang aktibidad

Magbasa pa sa [Impormasyon sa pagtatrabaho sa panahon ng COVID-19PDF (this is a pdf file)](https://www.dfeh.ca.gov/wp-content/uploads/sites/32/2020/03/DFEH-Employment-Information-on-COVID-19-FAQ_ENG.pdf) ng Departamento ng Patas na Trabaho at Pabahay (Department of Fair Employment and Housing, DFEH).

More info: [Mga Bakuna](https://covid19.ca.gov/tl/vaccines/)

Question: Paano nagpapasya ang estado kaugnay ng mga bakuna?
Answer:
Nagtutulungan ang isang [grupo ng mga eksperto](https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/Pages/COVID-19/Drafting-Guidelines-Workgroup.aspx/) at [grupo ng mga kinatawan sa komunidad](https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/Pages/COVID-19/Community-Vaccine-Advisory-Committee.aspx/) para matiyak na magiging patas ang pagbibigay ng priyoridad sa pamamahagi ng bakuna. 

Bumuo ang California ng [Pangkat sa Siyentipiko at Pangkaligtasang Pagsusuri ng Bakuna (Scientific Safety Review Workgroup)](https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/Pages/COVID-19/Scientific-Safety-Review-Workgroup.aspx) ng mga eksperto para matiyak ang kaligtasan ng mga bakuna laban sa COVID-19. Kinumpirma ng workgroup na ito na ay ligtas at epektibo ang mga bakunang pinahintulutan ng FDA.

More info: [Mga Bakuna](https://covid19.ca.gov/tl/vaccines/)

Question: Sino ang makakakuha ng mga bakuna para sa COVID-19 sa ngayon?
Answer: Tingnan kung [Sino ang puwedeng magpabakuna ngayon](/tl/vaccines/#Who-can-get-vaccinated-now)\n\nMore info: [Mga Bakuna](https://covid19.ca.gov/tl/vaccines/)

Question: Sino ang kwalipikado para sa pagbabakuna bilang Mga indibidwal na nasa mas malaking panganib?
Answer:
### Mga indibidwal na nasa mas malaking panganib

Available ang pagbabakuna para sa tinatayang 4.4 na milyong tao sa California na may mas malaking posibilidad na magkaroon ng malalang sakit dahil sa COVID-19. Kasama rito ang may ilang partikular na medikal na kundisyon, kapansanan, karamdaman, tirahan, o trabaho na nasa malaking panganib.

Ang mga indibidwal na may mga ganitong kondisyon ay labis na hinihikayat na makipag-ugnayan muna sa iyong karaniwang provider ng pangangalagang pangkalusugan. Maaari silang magpayo kung maaari kang magpabakuna sa kanila, o sa isang alternatibong klinika.

**Mga kondisyon sa kalusugan**

Puwedeng gamitin ng mga provider ng pangangalagang pangkalusugan ang kanilang klinikal na pagpapasya para bakunahan ang mga indibidwal na may edad na 16-64 na taon na [may napakalaking posibilidad](https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/Pages/COVID-19/Provider-Bulletin-2-12-21.aspx) na magkaroon ng napakalalang sakit dahil sa COVID-19 dahil sa mga sumusunod na malalang kundisyon sa kalusugan

*   **Cancer**, kasalukuyang may mahinang immune system
*   **Chronic kidney disease**, stage 4 pataas
*   **Chronic pulmonary disease,** umaasa sa oxygen
*   **Down syndrome**
*   **Solid organ transplant,** humahantong sa mahinang immune system
*   **Pagbubuntis**
*   **Sickle cell disease**
*   **Mga kundisyon sa puso**, gaya ng pagpalya ng puso, coronary artery disease, o cardiomyopathy (pero hindi altapresyon)
*   **Matinding obesity** (Body Mass Index ≥ 40 kg/m2)
*   **Type 2 diabetes mellitus** na may hemoglobin A1c level na mahigit 7.5%

**Mga kapansanan o karamdaman**

Maaari ding bakunahan ng mga provider ng pangangalagang pangkalusugan ang mga indibiduwal na may  kapansanan sa paglaki o iba pang malalang kapansanan o karamdaman kung:

*   Ang indibidwal ay malamang na magkaroon ng matinding karamdamang nakakamatay o malamang na mamatay dahil sa impeksyon sa COVID-19
*   Kapag nagkaroon ng COVID-19 ang indibidwal, malilimitahan ang kakahayan niya na makatanggap ng kasalukuyang panangalaga o mga serbsiyong mahalaga sa kanyang well-being o survival
*   Ang pagbibigay ng sapat at napapanahong pangangalaga laban sa COVID ay partikular na magiging mahirap bilang resulta ng kapansanan ng indibidwal.

Kasama rito ang mga taong may iba't ibang kapansanan sa pangangatawan at pag-uugali, gaya ng:

*   Mga taong may malalang sakit sa pag-iisip (Serious Mental Illness, SMI)
*   Iyong may malalang karamdaman sa labis na paggamit ng ipinagbabawal na gamot (substance use disorder, SUD)
*   Ang lahat ng naka-enroll na consumer ng:
    *   Mga regional center
    *   Mga independent living center 
    *   Mga pansuportang serbisyo sa bahay
    *   Mga serbisyo para sa nasa hustong gulang na nakabase sa komunidad/mga adult day health center
    *   Waiver sa Medi-Cal HIV/AIDS 
    *   Waiver sa mga alternatibo ng bahay at nakabase sa komunidad ng Medi-Cal
    *   Waiver sa ginagabayang pamumuhay ng Medi-Cal
    *   Mga programa ng all-inclusive care para sa matatanda 
    *   Programa ng mga serbisyo sa mga bata ng California (kung ang bata ay 16-21 taong gulang)
    *   Programa para sa mga genetically handicapped na tao

Tingnan ang [Paunawa ukol sa Impormasyon sa Pangangalagang PangkalusuganPDF (this is a pdf file)](https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/CDPH%20Document%20Library/COVID-19/Health-Care-Information-Notice-3-11-21.pdf) ng CDPH para sa mga detalye.

**Mga congregate living space** 

Ang mga indibidwal na naninirahan o nagtatrabaho sa isang congregate residential setting ay kwalipikado para sa bakuna laban sa COVID-19, kung saan kasama ang:  

*   Pasilidad ng incarceration/detention
*   Tirahan para sa mga walang bahay
*   Pasilidad ng kalusugang may kaugnayan sa pag-uugali. 

Ang mga setting na ito ay may mataas na panganib para sa mga outbreak at maraming indibidwal na may mataas na panganib na magkaroon ng mga pabalik-balik na kondisyon sa kalusugan. Kasama rito ang mga taong nakakaranas ng kawalan ng tirahan, na maaaring lumipat sa mga congregate setting nang may panandaliang abiso.

******Transportasyon at logistics – pampublikong transportasyon/paliparan at komersyal na airline******

Ang mga worker sa pampublikong transportasyon, kasama ang mga worker sa airport para sa mga komersyal na airline (pero hindi mga pribadong airplane), ay magiging kwalipikado para sa bakuna laban sa COVID-19. Mataas ang kanilang panganib na ma-expose sa trabaho, at ang pagpapatuloy ng mga operasyon sa transportasyon ay kritikal.

Alamin ang higit pa tungkol sa mga kinakailangan sa pagkakwalipikado mula sa CDPH:

*   [Na-update na Mga Alituntunin sa Pagkakwalipikado sa Bakuna laban sa COVID-19](https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/Pages/COVID-19/VaccineAllocationGuidelines.aspx) 
*   [Provider Bulletin](https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/Pages/COVID-19/Provider-Bulletin-2-12-21.aspx) 
*   [Papel ng impormasyon](https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/Pages/COVID-19/vaccine-high-risk-factsheet.aspx)

More info: [Mga Bakuna](https://covid19.ca.gov/tl/vaccines/)

Question: Kailan magsisimulang mabakunahan ang kalakhang publiko, na wala sa Phase 1? Saan ako puwedeng mag-sign up/magparehistro para maabisuhan kapag puwede na akong magpabakuna?
Answer:
### Sino ang susunod na babakunahan

Magkakaroon ang lahat ng Californian ng access sa mga bakuna laban sa COVID-19 pagsapit ng tagsibol 2021. 

Para maabisuhan kapag pagkakataon mo na, mag-sign up sa [myturn.ca.gov](https://myturn.ca.gov) o tumawag sa (833) 422-4255.

More info: [Mga Bakuna](https://covid19.ca.gov/tl/vaccines/)

Question: Paano ako makakapagpa-appintment para sa bakuna laban sa COVID-19 o makakapunta sa mga lokasyon ng pagbabakuna?
Answer:
### I-verify ang iyong pagiging kwalipikado o iskedyul gamit ang My Turn

Ang bawat Californian ay puwedeng mag-sign up sa [myturn.ca.gov](https://myturn.ca.gov) o tumawag sa (833) 422-4255 para malaman kung sila na ang dapat tumanggap ng bakuna laban sa COVID-19. 

Ang mga taong may mataas na panganib ng pagkaka-expose, nasa mataas na panganib, at iyong 65 taong gulang pataas ay kwalipikado para sa pagpapabakuna at puwede nang mag-iskedyul ng mga appointment ngayon. Kung kwalipikado ka, at nakatira o nagtatrabaho ka sa isang partikular na county, puwede kang magpaiskedyul ng appointment sa pamamagitan ng My Turn. Puwede ring magpa-appointment sa Spanish.

Kung hindi mo pa pagkakataon o walang available na appointment, puwede kang **mag-register para maabisuhan** kapag kwalipikado ka o magbubukas ng mga bagong iskedyul ng appointment.

More info: [Mga Bakuna](https://covid19.ca.gov/tl/vaccines/)

Question: Paano makakapagpaiskedyul ang mga guro at provider sa childcare para sa kanilang appointment sa pagbabakuna laban sa COVID-19?
Answer:
**Espesyal na **access**** **code para sa mga guro at provider ng childcare**

Magagawa ng mga guro at provider sa childcare na wala pang 65 taong gulang na mag-book ng appointment sa [myturn.ca.gov](https://myturn.ca.gov/) gamit ang isang espesyal na access code. Nakikipagtulungan ang estado sa mga lokal na organisasyon sa edukasyon at childcare para ipamahagi ang mga code na ito. Matuto pa tungkol sa [plano sa paglalaan ng bakuna para sa staff ng K-12 na paaralan at childcarePDF (this is a pdf file)](https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/CDPH%20Document%20Library/COVID-19/K-12_Vaccines_Overview.pdf).

### Magpaiskedyul sa isang lokal na provider.

Ang ilang [lokal na hurisdiksyon sa kalusugan](/tl/get-local-information/) ay nagbibigay ng mga appointment sa pagpapabakuna nang hiwalay sa My Turn.

Puwede mong gamitin ang tool na VaccineFinder ng CDC para makahanap ng mga lokasyon sa pagpapabakuna na malapit sa iyo:

More info: [Mga Bakuna](https://covid19.ca.gov/tl/vaccines/)

Question: Paano umeepekto ang mga bakuna laban sa COVID-19?
Answer: Tinuturuan ng mga bakuna sa COVID-19 ang ating mga immune system kung paano tukuyin at labanan ang virus na nagdudulot ng COVID-19. Kadalasang inaabot nang ilang linggo matapos ang pagpapabakuna bago makagawa ng proteksyon (immunity) ang katawan laban sa virus. Ibig sabihin ay posibleng makakuha pa rin ng COVID-19 ang isang tao matapos mabakunahan, dahil hindi nagkaroon ng sapat na panahon ang bakuna para makagawa ng immunity. \n\nMore info: [Mga Bakuna](https://covid19.ca.gov/tl/vaccines/)

Question: Gaano kaepektibo ang mga bakuna laban sa COVID-19?
Answer: Hanggang 95% mabisa ang mga awtorisadong bakuna sa pagpigil na mahawahan ng COVID-19 ang isang indibidwal.\n\nMore info: [Mga Bakuna](https://covid19.ca.gov/tl/vaccines/)

Question: Ligtas ba ang bakuna para sa COVID-19?
Answer:
Tinitiyak ng sistema sa kaligtasan ng bakuna ng U.S. na ligtas ang lahat ng bakuna, hangga't posible. Alamin kung paano kumikilos ang pederal na pamahalaan para [matiyak ang kaligtasan ng mga bakuna laban sa COVID-19](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/safety.html).

Milyon-milyon nang tao sa Estados Unidos ang nakatanggap ng bakuna laban sa COVID-19. Ang mga bakunang ito ay sumailalim sa pinakamatinding pag-monitor sa kaligtasan sa kasaysayan ng U.S., gamit ang kapwa [matagal na](https://vaers.hhs.gov/) at [bagong mga sistema sa pag-monitor ng kaligtasan](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/safety/vsafe.html). Hindi ka magkakaroon ng COVID-19 dahil sa mga bakunang ito. Alamin ang higit pang [impormasyon tungkol sa mga bakuna laban sa COVID-19](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/facts.html).

[Mas magbibigay ng katiyakan ang mga resulta mula sa mga pagmo-monitor](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/safety/adverse-events.html). Maraming tao ang nag-ulat lang ng mga bahagyang side effect matapos mabakunahan laban sa COVID-19. Ang ilang tao ay walang side effect.

More info: [Mga Bakuna](https://covid19.ca.gov/tl/vaccines/)

Question: Bakit ako dapat magpabakuna laban sa COVID-19?
Answer:
Ang mga bakuna laban sa COVID-19 ay mabisa at makakapigil sa pagkakaroon mo ng COVID-19. Pero may iba pang benepisyo ang mga ito:

*   Sa bihirang pagkakataon na magkaroon ka pa rin ng COVID-19, maaaring makatulong ang bakuna na hindi ka magkaroon ng malubhang karamdaman. 
*   Ang pagpapabakuna ay maaaring magprotekta rin sa mga tao sa paligid mo, [partikular na ang mga taong may mataas na panganib na magkaroon ng malubhang sakit na dulot ng COVID-19](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/need-extra-precautions/index.html).
*   Ang pagpapabakuna laban sa COVID-19 ay mas ligtas na paraan para makagawa ng immunity. Ang COVID-19 ay maaaring magkaroon ng [mga seryoso, mapanganib sa buhay na kumplikasyon,](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/symptoms-testing/symptoms.html) at walang paraan para malaman kung paano makakaapekto sa iyo ang COVID-19.

Ang pagpapabakuna laban sa COVID-19 ay isang mahalagang paraan para makabalik tayo sa normal.

Magbasa pa sa [Mga Benepisyo sa Pagpapabakuna Laban sa COVID-19](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/vaccine-benefits.html) ng CDC.

More info: [Mga Bakuna](https://covid19.ca.gov/tl/vaccines/)

Question: Ako ba ay pinapayagang magtrabaho sa panahon ng outbreak?
Answer:
Depende ito sa iyong trabaho. Ang sinumang miyembro ng [mahalagang lakas paggawaPDF (this is a pdf file)](https://files.covid19.ca.gov/pdf/EssentialCriticalInfrastructureWorkers.pdf) ay pinapayagang magtrabaho sa panahon ng [kautusang manatili sa bahay](/tl/stay-home-except-for-essential-needs/#top). At pinapayagang magtrabaho sa bahay ang mga empleyado na sinusuportahan ng kanilang employer na gawin ito.

Para sa impormasyon tungkol sa mga sektor ng negosyo at industriya na pinapayagang magbukas, bisitahin ang [gabay sa industriya](/tl/industry-guidance/).

More info: [Mga Manggagawa](https://covid19.ca.gov/tl/workers/)

Question: Ano ang maaari kong gawin kung ang aking oras ng trabaho ay nabawasan o hindi ako pinapasok  dahil sa COVID-19?
Answer: Maaari kang maghain ng [Insurance para sa Nawalan ng Trabaho (Unemployment Insurance o UI)](https://www.edd.ca.gov/Unemployment/Filing_a_Claim.htm).\n\nMore info: [Mga Manggagawa](https://covid19.ca.gov/tl/workers/)

Question: Kailangan ko ba ng isang nota o sertipikasyon mula sa sa doctor upang maghain ng walang trabaho?
Answer: Hindi kinakailangan ang medical certificate.\n\nMore info: [Mga Manggagawa](https://covid19.ca.gov/tl/workers/)

Question: Gaano katagal bago maproseso ang claim para sa unemployment or insurance benefits at makatanggap ng bayad?
Answer:
Pagkatapos naisumite ang iyong claim, magtatagal sa hindi bababa sa tatlong linggo upang maproseso. Maaaring mas matagal ito kung ang iyong impormasyon ay hindi pareho sa talaan at ang iyong pagkakakilanlan ay hindi maberipika. 

[Inalis ng Gobernador ang isang linggong paghihintay](https://www.gov.ca.gov/2020/03/12/governor-newsom-issues-new-executive-order-further-enhancing-state-and-local-governments-ability-to-respond-to-covid-19-pandemic/) . Ito ay nangangahulugan na maaari mong makuha ang mga benepisyo para sa unang linggo na ikaw ay nawalan ng trabaho o nabawasan ng oras sa trabaho.

More info: [Mga Manggagawa](https://covid19.ca.gov/tl/workers/)

Question: Maaari ba akong maghain ng reklamo sa kaligtasan sa lugar ng trabaho?
Answer: Oo, may karapatan kang maghain ng reklamo. Makakita ng [impormasyon at mga tagubilin](https://www.dir.ca.gov/dosh/complaint.htm) sa paghahain ng reklamo. Kung magsusumite ka ng reklamo, papanatilihing kumpidensyal ang iyong pangalan alinsunod sa batas.\n\nMore info: [Mga Manggagawa](https://covid19.ca.gov/tl/workers/)

Question: Ano ang maaari kong gawin kung nakaligtaan ko ang aking trabaho dahil sa pagsara ng mga paaralan?
Answer:
Maaari kang maghain ng [Insurance para sa Nawalan ng Trabaho (Unemployment Insurance o UI)](https://www.edd.ca.gov/Unemployment/Filing_a_Claim.htm). 

May ibang opsyon na magagamit. Tingnan ang [chart ng mga benepisyong ito para sa mga manggagawa na apektado ng COVID-19](https://www.labor.ca.gov/coronavirus2019/#chart).

More info: [Mga Manggagawa](https://covid19.ca.gov/tl/workers/)

Question: Paano kung hindi ako makapagtrabaho dahil ako ay nag-aalaga ng taong may sakit o na-quarantine?
Answer:
Puwede mong gamitin ang bayad na sick leave na naipon mo. Tingnan ang mga madalas itanong tungkol sa [bayad na sick leave ng California](https://www.dir.ca.gov/dlse/2019-Novel-Coronavirus.htm).

Maaari kang [maghain ng claim sa May Bayad na Pampamilyang Leave (PFL)](https://www.edd.ca.gov/Disability/How_to_File_a_PFL_Claim_in_SDI_Online.htm). Alamin kung kwalipikado ka para sa [bayad na family leave](https://edd.ca.gov/Disability/Am_I_Eligible_for_PFL_Benefits.htm). 

Tingnan ang chart ng [mga benepisyo para sa mga manggagawang naapektuhan ng COVID-19](https://www.labor.ca.gov/coronavirus2019/#chart) para malaman kung anong mga opsyon ang posibleng available sa iyo.

Posible kang makagamit ng pinoprotektahan ng trabaho na hindi bayad na leave. Tingnan ang mga madalas itanong ng Departamento sa Patas na Trabaho at Pabahay ng California tungkol sa [trabaho at COVID-19PDF (this is a pdf file)](https://www.dfeh.ca.gov/wp-content/uploads/sites/32/2020/03/DFEH-Employment-Information-on-COVID-19-FAQ_ENG.pdf).

More info: [Mga Manggagawa](https://covid19.ca.gov/tl/workers/)

Question: Ano ang maaari kong gawin kung hindi ako makapagtrabaho dahil ako ay may sakit o naka-quarantine dahil sa COVID-19?
Answer:
Mga sick leave sa pederal, estado, at sa ilang sitwasyon, sa lokal kung nakakaranas ka ng mga sintomas ng COVID-19, humihingi ng medikal na diagnosis, o nagka-quarantine.

Alamin kung anong mga benepisyo sa bayad na sick leave ang posibleng available sa iyo sa [paghahambing ng mga bayad na leave sa panahon ng COVID-19](https://www.dir.ca.gov/dlse/Comparison-COVID-19-Paid-Leave.html).

Ang ilang lokal na lokal na lugar ay may mga ordinansa sa bayad na sick leave, gaya ng San Jose, San Francisco, at Los Angeles. Kumonsulta sa lokal na ahensya ng pagpapatupad ng batas sa paggawa sa iyong lugar.

Puwede mong gamitin ang bayad na sick leave na naipon mo. Tingnan ang mga madalas itanong tungkol sa [bayad na sick leave ng California](https://www.dir.ca.gov/dlse/2019-Novel-Coronavirus.htm). 

Puwede kang [maghain ng claim sa Insurance sa Kapansanan (Disability Insurance, DI)](https://www.edd.ca.gov/Disability/How_to_File_a_DI_Claim_in_SDI_Online.htm) kung hindi ka nakakapagtrabaho dahil sa pagkakalantad sa COVID-19. Alamin kung kwalipikado ka para sa [mga benepisyo para sa insurance sa kapansanan](https://edd.ca.gov/Disability/Am_I_Eligible_for_DI_Benefits.htm). 

Puwede kang maghain ng [claim sa Workers’ Compensation](https://www.dir.ca.gov/dwc/FileAClaim.htm) kung nakuha mo ang COVID-19 sa iyong trabaho.

*   Ang ilang tayo ay puwedeng maging kwalipikado para sa workers’ compensation batay sa mga partikular na sitwasyon. Kasama sa mga ito ang:
    *   Mga first responder at manggagawa sa pangangalagang pangkalusugan na magkakasakit o magkakaroon ng pinsala dahil sa COVID-19 sa o bago ang Hulyo 6, 2020
    *   Mga empleyado ng mga kumpanyang may lima o higit pang empleyado na nagpositibo para sa COVID-19 sa panahon ng isang outbreak sa kanilang lugar sa trabaho
*   Tingnan ang mga madalas itanong tungkol sa kung sino ang puwedeng maging [kwalipikado para sa workers’ compensation](https://www.dir.ca.gov/dwc/Covid-19/FAQ-SB-1159.html) dahil sa COVID-19.

Tingnan ang chart ng [mga benepisyo para sa mga manggagawang naapektuhan ng COVID-19](https://www.labor.ca.gov/coronavirus2019/#chart) para malaman kung anong mga opsyon ang posibleng available sa iyo.

Posible kang makagamit ng pinoprotektahan ng trabaho na hindi bayad na leave. Tingnan ang mga madalas itanong ng Departamento sa Patas na Trabaho at Pabahay ng California tungkol sa [trabaho at COVID-19PDF (this is a pdf file)](https://www.dfeh.ca.gov/wp-content/uploads/sites/32/2020/03/DFEH-Employment-Information-on-COVID-19-FAQ_ENG.pdf).

More info: [Mga Manggagawa](https://covid19.ca.gov/tl/workers/)

Question: Paano kung ang mga pinagtratrabahuan ay walang nabayarang sick leave?
Answer:
Tingnan ang [chart ng available na bayad na leave](https://www.dir.ca.gov/dlse/Comparison-COVID-19-Paid-Leave.html) na posibleng sumaklaw sa mga manggagawa na may COVID-19.

Posible kang makagamit ng pinoprotektahan ng trabaho na hindi bayad na leave. Tingnan ang mga madalas itanong ng Departamento sa Patas na Trabaho at Pabahay ng California tungkol sa [trabaho at COVID-19PDF (this is a pdf file)](https://www.dfeh.ca.gov/wp-content/uploads/sites/32/2020/03/DFEH-Employment-Information-on-COVID-19-FAQ_ENG.pdf).

More info: [Mga Manggagawa](https://covid19.ca.gov/tl/workers/)

Question: Kinakailangan bang sabihin sa akin ng aking employer kung na-expose ako sa COVID-19 sa trabaho?
Answer:
Oo. Kung potensyal kang na-expose sa COVID-19 sa trabaho, dapat itong sabihin sa iyo ng iyong employer:

*   Sa loob ng isang araw ng negosyo
*   Ang tungkol sa mga available na benepisyo tulad ng mga bayad na leave at workers’ compensation
*   Ang tungkol sa kanilang plano sa pag-disinfect at kaligtasan

Para sa mga detalye tungkol sa mga ipinag-aatas na ito, tingnan ang [mga ipinag-aatas sa pag-uulat ng outbreak sa lugar ng trabaho](https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/Pages/COVID-19/ab685.aspx) ng California Department of Public Health.

More info: [Mga Manggagawa](https://covid19.ca.gov/tl/workers/)

Question: Kailan ako puwedeng bumalik sa trabaho kapag tapos na akong mag-isolate o mag-quarantine?
Answer:
Kung kailan ka makakabalik sa trabaho ay nakadepende sa iyong sitwasyon. 

Kung mayroon kang mga sintomas, [manatili sa bahay at mag-isolate](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/if-you-are-sick/steps-when-sick.html) hanggang sa:

*   Hindi bababa sa 10 araw na ang lumipas mula nang magsimula ang mga sintomas, AT
*    24 na oras ka nang walang lagnat nang hindi umiinom ng gamot, AT 
*   Bumuti na ang iyong [mga sintomas](/tl/symptoms-and-risks/#top) (gaya ng ubo at pangangapos ng hininga).

Totoo ito nagpositibo o nagnegatibo ka man, o hindi ka man nagpasuri.

Kung nagpositibo ka pero wala kang sintomas, [mag-isolate](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/if-you-are-sick/isolation.html "pumunta sa page na may impormasyon tungkol sa pag-isolate ng cdc.gov") sa bahay nang hindi bababa sa 10 araw.

Kung nagkaroon ka ng close contact sa isang taong nagpositibo pero nagnegatibo ka sa pagsusuri, dapat ka pa ring [mag-quarantine](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/if-you-are-sick/quarantine.html) sa bahay nang hindi bababa sa 10 araw. Tingnan ang [gabay sa quarantine](https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/Pages/COVID-19/COVID-19-Quarantine.aspx) ng California Department of Public Health para sa mga detalye.

Magpasuri kaagad kung mayroon kang mga sintomas o kung may nakaugnayan kang nagpositibo o may mga sintomas.

More info: [Mga Manggagawa](https://covid19.ca.gov/tl/workers/)

Question: Saan ako puwedeng mag-apply para sa kawalan ng trabaho?
Answer: Kung nawalan ka ng trabaho o nabawasan ang mga oras mo, at natutugunan mo ang mga kinakailangan sa pagiging kwalipikado, maaari kang maging kwalipikadong makatanggap ng mga benepisyo ng Insurance para sa Nawalan ng Trabaho (Unemployement Insurance, UI) mula sa Kagawaran ng California para sa Pagsusulong ng Trabaho (Employment Development Department). Tingnan ang [gabay sa pag-apply sa mga benepisyo para sa kawalan ng trabaho](https://unemployment.edd.ca.gov/guide).\n\nMore info: [Mga Manggagawa](https://covid19.ca.gov/tl/workers/)<!-- laid off, hours cut, lost my job, file for unemployment, file for UI -->

Question: Are there travel restrictions within California?
Answer:
On January 6, 2021, the California Department of Public Health issued a revised [Travel Advisory](https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/Pages/COVID-19/Travel-Advisory.aspx) that supersedes the previous Travel Advisory issued on November 13, 2020. This advisory affects all counties in California. 

To prevent further spread of COVID-19 and help contain any new sources of infection, Californians should stay within 120 miles from their home or other place of residence, unless they are traveling for essential purposes. Essential travel includes: work and study, critical infrastructure support, economic services and supply chains, health, immediate medical care, and safety and security.

Traveling into California from other states or countries for tourism or recreation is also strongly discouraged, and anyone traveling into California should self-quarantine for 10 days, unless quarantining is impracticable and the travel is for the sole purpose of meeting critical healthcare needs or other emergency response.   

See the California Department of Public Health’s [Travel Advisory](https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/Pages/COVID-19/Travel-Advisory.aspx) for more info.

More info: [Travel](https://covid19.ca.gov/travel/)

Question: Do I need to self-quarantine when I arrive in California?
Answer:
Traveling into California for tourism or recreation is strongly discouraged. If you do travel into California, you should [self-quarantinePDF (this is a pdf file)](https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/CDPH%20Document%20Library/COVID-19/CDPH-Home-Quarantine-Guidance_9-16-2020.pdf) for 10 days after you arrive, and should limit your interactions to people in your household. If you are traveling into California for essential purposes, you should still self-quarantine for 10 days and ensure you do not mix with others outside of those necessary to conduct your essential work. The only exception to the quarantine period is if you are in California to meet urgent critical healthcare needs or any other emergent response. In these cases, strictly adhere to [face coverings](https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/Pages/COVID-19/guidance-for-face-coverings.aspx) and physical distancing guidelines.

If you routinely cross state or country borders for essential travel, and self-quarantine is impractical, you must still comply with all required guidance related to [face coverings](https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/Pages/COVID-19/guidance-for-face-coverings.aspx) and physical distancing to reduce the risk of spread of the virus.

More info: [Travel](https://covid19.ca.gov/travel/)

Question: Can I visit State Parks? What outdoor spaces are open?
Answer:
Outdoor spaces, including state parks, **may** be open to facilitate physically distanced personal health and wellness through outdoor exercise. However, be sure to check the status of parks in your area before you travel as some State Parks may continue to be closed to help slow the spread of the virus.

For information on National Parks, please the [National Park Service website](https://www.nps.gov/aboutus/news/public-health-update.htm).

[Outdoor playgrounds](https://covid19.ca.gov/industry-guidance/#campgrounds-outdoor-recreation) may be open if they are free to enter and use and primarily serve nearby residents. Your local health department may have additional restrictions. Check [your county’s COVID-19 website](https://covid19.ca.gov/get-local-information/#County-websites) for information on playgrounds in your community.

Californians should not travel more than 120 miles from their home for non-essential purposes such as pleasure or recreation. If you do travel, take steps to keep everyone safe like wearing a face covering, keeping 6 feet of physical distance from those not in your household, and washing your hands frequently.

See the California Department of Public Health’s [Travel Advisory](https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/Pages/COVID-19/Travel-Advisory.aspx) for more info.

More info: [Travel](https://covid19.ca.gov/travel/)<!-- park, visitor center, travel, museum, RV parks, recreation, outdoor recreation, sports, RV, tent camping, tent camp, fish, beach, lake, river, event, outdoor event, event planning, hike, walk, bike, exercise, nature, bird watching, public -->

Question: What is an FDA Emergency Use Authorization (EUA)?
Answer:
It is a way for the FDA to provide faster access to medicines and treatments during a health emergency. These can include products that are still being studied. This may help when there are no other adequate, approved, and available options. EUAs are in effect until the emergency declaration ends. The FDA can revise or revoke EUAs according to its evaluation of the needs during the emergency. EUAs may also change as the FDA approves, clears, or licenses the medicines or treatments.

For more on this subject, see

*   [FDA: Emergency Use Authorization](https://www.fda.gov/emergency-preparedness-and-response/mcm-legal-regulatory-and-policy-framework/emergency-use-authorization#coviddrugs)
*   [FDA video “What is an EUA?”](https://youtu.be/iGkwaESsGBQ) 

More info: [Treatment](https://covid19.ca.gov/treatment-for-covid-19/)

Question: Has the FDA issued any Emergency Use Authorizations (EUAs) for treatment of COVID-19 outside hospitals?
Answer:
Yes. The FDA has issued a few EUAs for monoclonal antibody drugs:

*   Bamlanivimab
*   Bamlanivimab and etesevimab, administered together
*   Casirivimab and imdevimab, administered together

Authorizations are for:

*   Non-hospitalized patients with mild or moderate COVID-19.
*   Adult and pediatric patients 12 years of age and older weighing at least 88 pounds. 
*   Patients at high risk for progressing to severe COVID-19 or hospitalization. This includes those who are 65 years of age or older, or who have certain chronic medical conditions.

The drugs are administered as a single dose intravenously by health care providers.

These drugs are not authorized for use in COVID-19 patients requiring:

*   Hospitalization
*   Oxygen therapy
*   An increase in baseline oxygen flow due to underlying non-COVID-19-related conditions

Patients treated with these drugs should continue to:

*   Self-isolate
*   Wear a mask 
*   Socially distance 
*   Avoid sharing personal items 
*   Clean and disinfect “high touch” surfaces 
*   Frequently wash their hands

Find out more about these treatments from the FDA:

*   [Monoclonal Antibody Bamlanivimab for Treatment of COVID-19](https://www.fda.gov/news-events/press-announcements/coronavirus-covid-19-update-fda-authorizes-monoclonal-antibody-treatment-covid-19)
*   [Monoclonal Antibody Bamlanivimab and Etesevimab for Treatment of COVID-19](https://www.fda.gov/news-events/press-announcements/coronavirus-covid-19-update-fda-authorizes-monoclonal-antibodies-treatment-covid-19-0)
*   [Monoclonal Antibodies Casirivimab and Imdevimab for Treatment of COVID-19](https://www.fda.gov/news-events/press-announcements/coronavirus-covid-19-update-fda-authorizes-monoclonal-antibodies-treatment-covid-19)
*   [Frequently Asked Questions on the Emergency Use Authorization for Bamlanivimab](https://www.fda.gov/media/143605/download) 
*   [Frequently Asked Questions on the Emergency Use Authorization for Bamlanivimab and Etesevimab](https://www.fda.gov/media/145808/download)
*   [Frequently Asked Questions on the Emergency Use Authorization of Casirivimab + Imdevimab](https://www.fda.gov/media/143894/download)

More info: [Treatment](https://covid19.ca.gov/treatment-for-covid-19/)

Question: Has the FDA approved any treatment for hospitalized COVID-19 patients?
Answer:
Yes, the FDA has [approved the antiviral drug Veklury (remdesivir)](https://www.fda.gov/news-events/press-announcements/fda-approves-first-treatment-covid-19#:~:text=Today%2C%20the%20U.S.%20Food%20and,of%20COVID%2D19%20requiring%20hospitalization.) for these patients. Veklury should only be used in a hospital or in a healthcare setting capable of providing acute care. 

Note that the FDA changed who can receive this drug under the EUA to ensure continued access to it for certain pediatric patients.

For more information, see [Frequently Asked Questions about the Remdesivir EUA](https://www.fda.gov/media/137574/download) (PDF).

More info: [Treatment](https://covid19.ca.gov/treatment-for-covid-19/)

Question: Has the FDA issued any Emergency Use Authorizations (EUAs) for treatment of COVID-19 inside hospitals?
Answer:
Yes. The FDA has issued two EUAs for COVID-19 treatment in hospitalized patients:

*   Veklury (**remdesivir)** is an anti-viral drug that is injected. The EUA authorizes Veklury for use by licensed healthcare providers to treat:
    *   hospitalized children weighing 8-88 pounds, or
    *   hospitalized pediatric patients less than 12 years of age weighing at least 8 pounds.  
          
        For more information, see  
        – [Frequently Asked Questions about the Remdesivir EUA](https://www.fda.gov/media/137574/download) (PDF)  
        – [Fact Sheet for Patients and Parents/Caregivers](https://www.fda.gov/media/137565/download) (PDF)  
        – [Remdesivir Information for Patients and Parents/Caregivers](https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/Pages/COVID-19/RemdesivirInformationforPatientsandParentsCaregivers.aspx)

**COVID-19 Convalescent Plasma** is blood plasma from someone who has recovered from COVID-19. It may have antibodies which can help a person who is sick with COVID-19.

For more information, see [Fact Sheet for Patients and Parents/Caregivers on COVID-19 Convalescent Plasma](https://www.fda.gov/media/141479/download) (PDF).

More info: [Treatment](https://covid19.ca.gov/treatment-for-covid-19/)

Question: Are there medications available for hospitalized COVID-19 patients on ventilators?
Answer:
Yes. **Dexamethasone** is an anti-inflammatory medication. It’s recommended for hospitalized COVID-19 patients using a ventilator or supplemental oxygen.

For more information, see [NIH’s Therapeutic Management of Patients with COVID-19](https://www.covid19treatmentguidelines.nih.gov/therapeutic-management/).

More info: [Treatment](https://covid19.ca.gov/treatment-for-covid-19/)

Question: When should I seek emergency treatment?
Answer:
If you develop any of these symptoms of COVID-19, get medical attention immediately:

*   Trouble breathing
*   Persistent pain or pressure in the chest
*   New confusion 
*   Inability to awake or stay awake
*   Bluish lips or face

There are other, less-common symptoms. Please call your medical provider if you have any symptoms that are severe or concern you.

If you need to go to the hospital, call ahead so they can prepare for your arrival. If you call 911, tell the operator you have coronavirus symptoms. This is so ambulance workers can be ready to treat you safely.

Not sure if this applies to you? Check your symptoms with the [Symptom Screener](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/symptoms-testing/symptoms.html?CDC_AA_refVal=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.cdc.gov%2Fcoronavirus%2F2019-ncov%2Fsymptoms-testing%2Findex.html) or contact your doctor through [telehealth](https://covid19.ca.gov/telehealth/).

More info: [Treatment](https://covid19.ca.gov/treatment-for-covid-19/)

Question: When can I be around other people after I had COVID-19 with symptoms?
Answer:
You can be with others after:

*   10 days since symptoms first appeared **and**
*   At least 24 hours with no fever without fever-reducing medication **and**
*   After symptoms have improved

CDC has [detailed recommendations](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/if-you-are-sick/end-home-isolation.html) on this for people who had COVID-19 with symptoms.

More info: [Treatment](https://covid19.ca.gov/treatment-for-covid-19/)

Question: Can two people that both tested positive hang out/stay together?
Answer: No. You should take preventive measures to protect yourself and others. We do not know yet if or when a person can be reinfected with COVID-19. \n\nMore info: [Treatment](https://covid19.ca.gov/treatment-for-covid-19/)

Question: Individuals at higher risk
Answer:
Vaccinations are available for the estimated 4.4 million people in California at higher risk for serious COVID-19 illness. This includes those with certain significant high-risk medical conditions, disabilities, illness, living spaces, or work environments.

Individuals with these conditions are strongly encouraged to check first with your usual health care provider. They can advise if you can get your vaccination with them, or in an alternate clinical setting.

**Health conditions**

Healthcare providers may use their clinical judgement to vaccinate individuals aged 16-64 who are [deemed to be at highest risk](https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/Pages/COVID-19/Provider-Bulletin-2-12-21.aspx) to get very sick from COVID-19 due to the following severe health conditions:

*   **Cancer**, current with weakened immune system
*   **Chronic kidney disease**, stage 4 or above
*   **Chronic pulmonary disease,** oxygen dependent
*   **Down syndrome**
*   **Solid organ transplant,** leading to a weakened immune system
*   **Pregnancy**
*   **Sickle cell disease**
*   **Heart conditions**, such as heart failure, coronary artery disease, or cardiomyopathies (but not hypertension)
*   **Severe obesity** (Body Mass Index ≥ 40 kg/m2)
*   **Type 2 diabetes mellitus** with hemoglobin A1c level greater than 7.5%

**Disabilities or illness**

Healthcare providers may also vaccinate individuals with  developmental or other severe disabilities or illness if:

*   The individual is likely to develop severe life-threatening illness or death from COVID-19 infection
*   Acquiring COVID-19 will limit the individual’s ability to get ongoing care or services vital to their well-being and survival
*   Providing adequate and timely COVID care will be particularly challenging as a result of the individual’s disability.

These include people with a range of physical and behavioral disabilities, such as:

*   People with serious mental illness (SMI)
*   Those with serious substance use disorder (SUD)
*   All enrolled consumers of:
    *   Regional centers
    *   Independent living centers 
    *   In-home supportive services
    *   Community-based adult services/adult day health centers
    *   Medi-Cal HIV/AIDS waiver 
    *   Medi-Cal home and community-based alternatives waiver
    *   Medi-Cal assisted living waiver
    *   Programs of all-inclusive care for the elderly 
    *   California children’s services program (if the child is 16-21 years old)
    *   California genetically handicapped persons program

See CDPH’s [Health Care Information NoticePDF (this is a pdf file)](https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/CDPH%20Document%20Library/COVID-19/Health-Care-Information-Notice-3-11-21.pdf) for details.

**Congregate living spaces** 

Individuals who live or work in a congregate residential setting are eligible for COVID-19 vaccination, which includes:  

*   Incarceration/detention facility
*   Homeless shelter
*   Behavioral health facility. 

These settings are at high risk for outbreaks and have a concentration of individuals with high-risk chronic health conditions. This includes people experiencing homelessness, who may transition into congregate settings at short notice.

******Transportation and logistics – public transit/airport and commercial airlines******

Public transit workers, including airport workers for commercial airlines (but not private airplanes), will be eligible for COVID-19 vaccination. They are at high risk for occupational exposure, and maintaining continuity of transportation operations is critical.

Find out more about eligibility requirements from the CDPH:

*   [Updated COVID-19 Vaccine Eligibility Guidelines](https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/Pages/COVID-19/VaccineAllocationGuidelines.aspx) 
*   [Provider Bulletin](https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/Pages/COVID-19/Provider-Bulletin-2-12-21.aspx) 
*   [Fact sheet](https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/Pages/COVID-19/vaccine-high-risk-factsheet.aspx)

More info: [Vaccines](https://covid19.ca.gov/vaccines/)

Question: Equity for hardest-hit communities
Answer:
California must end the COVID-19 pandemic as quickly and effectively as possible by vaccinating those most at risk of serious outcomes and those who have been most exposed at work or in their daily lives. This will protect not just those who are vaccinated, but reduce additional community transmission. By targeting vaccines to those who most need them, we can also begin to [safely reopen activities](https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/Pages/COVID-19/BlueprintForSaferEconomy.aspx) across our economy.  

The state will continue to double the amount of vaccine allocated to the lowest HPI quartile as [announced on March 4](https://www.gov.ca.gov/2021/03/04/california-leads-with-public-health-and-vaccine-equity-to-safely-and-sustainably-reopen/) for four weeks beginning the week of March 22.

Currently, the state [is directing 40% of vaccine doses to the hardest-hit areas of the state](https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/OPA/Pages/NR21-072.aspx) based on the lowest quartile of the Public Health Alliance of Southern California’s Healthy Places Index (HPI). Our next goal is to reach 4 million vaccine doses administered to the hardest-hit communities in the state, which represents about 25 percent of eligible Californians.

More info: [Vaccines](https://covid19.ca.gov/vaccines/)

Question: How are vaccines allocated?
Answer:
Once a week, the federal government announces anticipated allocation figures for each state. The number of allocated doses provided by the federal government is a projection and subject to change. 

Using the federal allocation as a starting point, the state considers recommendations from the leadership of local health jurisdictions and the state’s third-party administrator, Blue Shield of California, to make decisions about how best to allocate vaccine supply in the state for efficient and equitable delivery of vaccinations. In addition to adjusting allocations to target eligible populations the state [is directing 40% of vaccine doses to the hardest hit areas of the state](https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/OPA/Pages/NR21-072.aspx) based on the lowest quartile of the Healthy Places Index (HPI). See the [most recent allocation](https://public.tableau.com/profile/ca.open.data#!/vizhome/COVID-19VaccineAllocationbyLHJ/AllocationbyCounty)**.**

More info: [Vaccines](https://covid19.ca.gov/vaccines/)

Question: How are vaccines distributed?
Answer: Local providers place orders which are reviewed by the state and submitted to the federal government. The federal government then authorizes the order and submits the request to the manufacturer. The manufacturer or central distributor ships the vaccine directly to local providers. It can take a week or longer for allocation by the federal government to arrive at public health offices or providers for administration.\n\nMore info: [Vaccines](https://covid19.ca.gov/vaccines/)

Question: How can I sign-up to be a COVID-19 vaccine provider?
Answer: See [myCAvax Provider EnrollmentPDF (this is a pdf file)](https://eziz.org/assets/other/IMM-1295.pdf) instructions for steps to sign up. Also read the CDPH’s COVID-19 vaccine provider [enrollment](https://eziz.org/covid/enrollment/) and [training](https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/Pages/Immunization/COVID-19VaccineTraining.aspx) requirements.\n\nMore info: [Vaccines](https://covid19.ca.gov/vaccines/)

Question: How many COVID-19 vaccine doses are needed?
Answer:
*   Two doses for the Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine, 21 days apart
*   Two doses for the Moderna vaccine, 28 days apart
*   One dose for the Johnson & Johnson/Janssen vaccine

If two shots are required, ****get your second shot as close to the recommended interval as possible****, but not sooner. However, if you can’t get it at the recommended interval, second doses may be given up to 6 weeks (42 days) after the first dose. There is limited data on how well these vaccines work beyond this window. But if the second dose is given after 42 days, there is no need to start over.

Be sure to get the same vaccine the second time that you got the first time. COVID-19 vaccines are not interchangeable with each other. The safety and efficacy of mixing vaccines has not been tested.

More info: [Vaccines](https://covid19.ca.gov/vaccines/)

Question: How much will the COVID-19 vaccine cost?
Answer:
Nothing. COVID-19 vaccines, including their administration, are free.

Read more at the Department of Managed Health Care’s [Know Your Health Care RightsPDF (this is a pdf file)](https://www.dmhc.ca.gov/Portals/0/Docs/DO/VaccineFactSheetAccessible.pdf).

More info: [Vaccines](https://covid19.ca.gov/vaccines/)

Question: Do I need to be a California resident to get COVID-19 vaccine?
Answer: No. Vaccine distribution is based on eligibility irrespective of residency or immigration status.\n\nMore info: [Vaccines](https://covid19.ca.gov/vaccines/)

Question: Who are the agriculture and food sector populations for COVID-19 vaccination?
Answer:
The agriculture and food sector populations (under [Phase 1B](https://covid19.ca.gov/vaccines/#Who-can-get-vaccinated-now)) for COVID-19 vaccination include:

*   Persons at risk of occupational exposure to coronavirus through their work in any role in he [Food and Agriculture Sector from CA Essential Workforce](https://covid19.ca.gov/essential-workforce/#food-and-agriculture) list.
*   Any employee working in a restaurant to the extent not described in the food and agriculture sector from the CA Essential Worker list.
*   Veterinary services employees.
*   Medical cannabis workers.

See CDPH’s [Updated COVID-19 Vaccine Eligibility Guidelines](https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/Pages/COVID-19/VaccineAllocationGuidelines.aspx) for details.

More info: [Vaccines](https://covid19.ca.gov/vaccines/)

Question: Who are the emergency services sector populations for COVID-19 vaccination?
Answer:
The emergency services sector populations (under [Phase 1B](https://covid19.ca.gov/vaccines/#Who-can-get-vaccinated-now)) for COVID-19 vaccination include:

*   Persons at risk of occupational exposure to coronavirus through their work in any role in the [**Emergency Services Sectors** from the CA Essential Workforce](https://covid19.ca.gov/essential-workforce/#emergency-services) list.
*   Utility Workers (Electricity, gas, water, waste, roads/highways) that provide emergency support. 
*   Disaster Service Workers (DSWs) if at risk of occupational exposure, once activated for emergency response, including those working in temporary non-congregate shelters.
*   COVID-19 vaccine clinic volunteers are eligible for vaccination if they complete at least one clinic shift and are approved by the clinic’s organizer.
*   Social Workers. Workers responding to abuse and neglect of children, elders and dependent adults, including all front-line social workers and other staff required to enter the home (including mobile home or tent) of the individual at risk.

See CDPH’s [Updated COVID-19 Vaccine Eligibility Guidelines](https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/Pages/COVID-19/VaccineAllocationGuidelines.aspx) for details.

More info: [Vaccines](https://covid19.ca.gov/vaccines/)

Question: Who are the education and childcare sector populations for COVID-19 vaccination?
Answer:
The education and childcare sector populations (under [Phase 1B](https://covid19.ca.gov/vaccines/#Who-can-get-vaccinated-now)) for COVID-19 vaccination include:

*   All formal and informal childcare workers, including day care providers and the following:
    *   Public and private recreation programs such as YMCA/YWCA
    *   On campus after school programs
    *   Individuals or programs receiving a child care subsidy. 
    *   Occasional babysitting should not be included 
*   Resource family approved homes and certified family homes providing emergency or short-term foster care. While foster care is in a home care setting, the nature of it is temporary and may be a revolving door of children staying and leaving needing care.  
*   Those working in Children’s Residential Community Care facilities 
*   All staff in colleges, universities, junior colleges, community colleges, and other postsecondary education facilities
*   All staff in educational support services and administration
*   All staff in Pre-kindergarten, elementary, middle, and high schools
*   All staff in technical and trade schools
*   Any other workers involved in child and/or student care, including school bus drivers and monitors, crosswalk guards, etc.
*   Library staff with occupational exposure to students

See CDPH’s [Updated COVID-19 Vaccine Eligibility Guidelines](https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/Pages/COVID-19/VaccineAllocationGuidelines.aspx) for details.

More info: [Vaccines](https://covid19.ca.gov/vaccines/)

Question: Are massage therapists eligible for the COVID-19 vaccine under Phase 1A?
Answer: Yes, massage therapists are considered [Phase 1A](https://covid19.ca.gov/vaccines/#Who-can-get-vaccinated-now) under Alternative Medical Practitioners.\n\nMore info: [Vaccines](https://covid19.ca.gov/vaccines/)

Question: Are janitors eligible for the COVID-19 vaccine now?
Answer: Yes, janitors are eligible for a vaccine. Janitors provide support to the health care, emergency services, and education sectors for [Phase 1A and Phase 1B](https://covid19.ca.gov/vaccines/#Who-can-get-vaccinated-now). This includes a vast majority of sectors with janitorial support. As a practical matter and for ease of implementation, all janitors are eligible.\n\nMore info: [Vaccines](https://covid19.ca.gov/vaccines/)

Question: I’ve already had COVID-19. Should I get a COVID-19 vaccine?
Answer: Yes. We do not know how long someone is protected from getting sick again after recovering from COVID-19.\n\nMore info: [Vaccines](https://covid19.ca.gov/vaccines/)

Question: Can I get vaccinated against COVID-19 while I am currently sick with COVID-19?
Answer: No. People with COVID-19 who have symptoms should wait to be vaccinated until they have recovered from their illness and have met the [criteria](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/hcp/disposition-in-home-patients.html) for ending isolation. Those without symptoms should also wait until they [meet the criteria](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/if-you-are-sick/quarantine.html) before getting vaccinated. This guidance also applies to people who get COVID-19 before getting their second dose of vaccine.\n\nMore info: [Vaccines](https://covid19.ca.gov/vaccines/)

Question: How do people with these high-risk conditions or disabilities get a COVID-19 vaccine?
Answer:
There are five ways you can find an appointment. Vaccine supply remains limited nationwide.

1.  Your healthcare provider: Check first with your usual health care provider to see if they have vaccines. Those who have vaccines may also begin reaching out to you to schedule your vaccine appointment.
2.  Pharmacies: You can check your local pharmacies to see if they have vaccines and available appointments. 
3.  Your local health department: Your local health department’s website will have information about how to find available vaccine appointments, even as national supply remains limited.
4.  Community pop-up clinics: These clinics for people with high-risk medical conditions and disabilities are targeted for equity to those living in communities with the lowest Healthy Places Index (HPI) scores. Community partners will reach out to people eligible for the pop-up clinics.
5.  MyTurn: Throughout the spring you will be able to schedule an appointment through California’s MyTurn, in two ways:
    *   Online at [myturn.ca.gov](http://www.myturn.ca.gov). The MyTurn website is accessible to people with disabilities and in eight languages:
        *   English
        *   Spanish
        *   Simplified and traditional Chinese
        *   Tagalog
        *   Korean
        *   Arabic
        *   Vietnamese
    *   By calling the COVID-19 Hotline at 1-833-422-4255 or 1-833-4CA-4ALL (M-F 8AM-8PM, Sa-Su 8AM-5PM). The hotline is accessible to people with disabilities and offers services in English and Spanish.  It also provides connections to interpretive services in more than 250 languages.

You will be asked to state that you have a high-risk medical condition or disability, either to book an available appointment or to register for notice of future appointments made available as supply increases. You will be able to request an accommodation at your vaccine site through MyTurn.  

More info: [Vaccines](https://covid19.ca.gov/vaccines/)

Question: Will I need to verify I have a high-risk medical condition or disability when I go to my appointment?
Answer: To protect confidentiality, verification of the diagnosis or type of disability is not required. Instead, anyone meeting the eligibility requirements will be asked to sign a self-attestation that they meet the criteria for high-risk medical conditions or disabilities.\n\nMore info: [Vaccines](https://covid19.ca.gov/vaccines/)

Question: Will COVID-19 vaccine sites be accessible?
Answer: Yes. All vaccine clinics in California are required to ensure sites and services are accessible in accordance with ADA (Americans with Disabilities Act) requirements.\n\nMore info: [Vaccines](https://covid19.ca.gov/vaccines/)

Question: How do I get a COVID-19 vaccine at home, if I am unable to travel to a vaccine site?
Answer: Check with your healthcare provider, local health department, or local pharmacy.\n\nMore info: [Vaccines](https://covid19.ca.gov/vaccines/)

Question: How do I get transportation to a vaccine site?
Answer:
Check with your healthcare provider, local health department, or local pharmacy.

If you receive Medi-Cal through a managed care plan, contact your plan’s member service department to request assistance for transportation to receive covered benefits. If you receive Medi-Cal through Fee-for-Service (FFS), you can access a list of Non-Medical Transportation (NMT) providers in your county and you can contact them directly to arrange transportation to your appointments. 

If there is not a provider in your area, the California Department of Health Care Services (DHCS) can assist if you email them DHCSNMT@dhcs.ca.gov. Please do NOT include personal information in your first email. DHCS staff will reply with a secure email asking for your information about the appointment. 

If you have a need for Non-Emergency Medical Transportation, please inform your medical provider who can prescribe this service and put you in touch with a transportation provider to coordinate your ride to and from your appointment(s).

More info: [Vaccines](https://covid19.ca.gov/vaccines/)

Question: Will the COVID-19 vaccine make me test positive for COVID-19?
Answer:
No. A vaccine will not cause you to test positive on [viral tests](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/testing/diagnostic-testing.html).

If your body develops an immune response (the goal of vaccination), there is a possibility that you may test positive on [antibody tests](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/testing/serology-overview.html). Antibody tests indicate that you may have protection against the virus.

More info: [Vaccines](https://covid19.ca.gov/vaccines/)

Question: How is my privacy protected if I take the COVID-19 vaccine?
Answer:
California law strictly limits how personal information about those who are vaccinated can be shared. California negotiated with the federal government to limit the required data sharing to only information that will not allow an individual to be identified.

Read more at CDPH’s [California Data Use Agreement and Frequently Asked Questions](https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/Pages/COVID-19/California-Data-Use-Agreement.aspx).

More info: [Vaccines](https://covid19.ca.gov/vaccines/)

Question: I have allergies. Should I get the COVID-19 vaccine?
Answer:
It depends. [CDC recommends](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/safety/allergic-reaction.html) that:

*   If you have had a severe allergic reaction or an immediate allergic reaction—even if it was not severe—to any ingredient in an mRNA COVID-19 vaccine, you should not get either of the currently available mRNA COVID-19 vaccines (Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna).
*   If you have had a severe allergic reaction or an immediate allergic reaction to any ingredient in Johnson & Johnson’s Janssen COVID-19 vaccine, you should not get the J&J/Janssen vaccine.
*   If you had an immediate allergic reaction after getting the first dose of an mRNA COVID-19 vaccine, you should not get the second dose.  
*   If you are allergic to PEG, you should not get an mRNA COVID-19 vaccine. Ask your doctor if you can get the Janssen vaccine.
*   If you are allergic to polysorbate, you should not get the Janssen vaccine. Ask your doctor if you can get an mRNA COVID-19 vaccine.
*   If you aren’t able to get one type of COVID-19 vaccine because you are allergic to an ingredient, ask your doctor if you should get a different vaccine. 
*   If you aren’t able to get the second shot of an mRNA vaccine because you had an allergic reaction, ask your doctor if you should get a different vaccine.
*   If you have had a severe allergic reaction to other vaccines or injections, you should ask your doctor if you should get a COVID-19 vaccine.
*   People with a history of severe allergic reactions not related to vaccines or injections may still get vaccinated. People may get vaccinated even with a:
    *   History of allergies to oral medications
    *   Family history of severe allergic reactions
    *   Milder allergy to vaccines

More info: [Vaccines](https://covid19.ca.gov/vaccines/)

Question: What are the ingredients in COVID-19 vaccines?
Answer:
The ingredients in the Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna vaccines include:

*   mRNA
*   Lipids
*   Salts
*   Sugars
*   Buffers 

Buffers help maintain the stability of the pH solution. 

The Janssen vaccine includes the following ingredients: 

*   Recombinant, replication-incompetent adenovirus type 26 expressing the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein
*   Citric acid monohydrate
*   Trisodium citrate dihydrate
*   Ethanol
*   2-hydroxypropyl-β-cyclodextrin (HBCD), polysorbate-80
*   Sodium chloride

These vaccines do not contain:

*   Eggs
*   Preservatives
*   Latex

To learn more about the ingredients in authorized COVID-19 vaccines, see

*   [Information about the Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 vaccine](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/different-vaccines/Pfizer-BioNTech.html)
*   [Information about the Moderna COVID-19 vaccine](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/different-vaccines/Moderna.html)
*   [Information About Johnson & Johnson’s Janssen COVID-19 Vaccine](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/different-vaccines/janssen.html)

More info: [Vaccines](https://covid19.ca.gov/vaccines/)

Question: Are there certain populations who should not get a COVID-19 vaccine?
Answer:
The [CDC recommends](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/safety/allergic-reaction.html) that:

*   If you have had a severe allergic reaction or an immediate allergic reaction—even if it was not severe—to any ingredient in an mRNA COVID-19 vaccine, you should not get either of the currently available mRNA COVID-19 vaccines (Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna).
*   If you have had a severe allergic reaction or an immediate allergic reaction to any ingredient in Johnson & Johnson’s Janssen COVID-19 vaccine, you should not get the J&J/Janssen vaccine.
*   If you had an immediate allergic reaction after getting the first dose of an mRNA COVID-19 vaccine, you should not get the second dose.  
*   If you are allergic to PEG, you should not get an mRNA COVID-19 vaccine. Ask your doctor if you can get the Janssen vaccine.
*   If you are allergic to polysorbate, you should not get the Janssen vaccine. Ask your doctor if you can get an mRNA COVID-19 vaccine.
*   If you aren’t able to get one type of COVID-19 vaccine because you are allergic to an ingredient, ask your doctor if you should get a different vaccine. 
*   If you aren’t able to get the second shot of an mRNA vaccine because you had an allergic reaction, ask your doctor if you should get a different vaccine.

People with underlying medical conditions can receive the FDA-authorized COVID-19 vaccines provided they have not had [an immediate or severe allergic reaction](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/safety/allergic-reaction.html) to a COVID-19 vaccine or to any of the ingredients in the vaccine. Learn more about vaccination [considerations for people with underlying medical conditions.](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/recommendations/underlying-conditions.html) Vaccination is an important consideration for adults of any age with certain underlying medical conditions because they are at increased risk for severe illness from the virus that causes COVID-19.

More info: [Vaccines](https://covid19.ca.gov/vaccines/)

Question: Can pregnant or breastfeeding women be vaccinated against COVID-19?
Answer:
Yes. The [CDC recommends](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/recommendations/pregnancy.html) that if you are pregnant, you may choose to be vaccinated when it’s available to you. There is currently no evidence that antibodies formed from COVID-19 vaccination cause any problem with pregnancy, including the development of the placenta.

People who are trying to become pregnant now or who plan to try in the future may also receive the COVID-19 vaccine when it becomes available to them. There is no evidence that fertility problems are a side effect of any vaccine, including COVID-19 vaccines. There is no routine recommendation for taking a pregnancy test before you get a COVID-19 vaccine.If you have questions about getting vaccinated, talk with a healthcare provider to help you make an informed decision.

More info: [Vaccines](https://covid19.ca.gov/vaccines/)

Question: How long should I wait to get the vaccine after I had COVID-19?
Answer:
The [CDC recommends:](https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/covid-19/info-by-product/clinical-considerations.html?CDC_AA_refVal=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.cdc.gov%2Fvaccines%2Fcovid-19%2Finfo-by-product%2Fpfizer%2Fclinical-considerations.html)

*   If you tested positive, had only mild symptoms, and were not treated for the coronavirus, you should wait at least 10 days since the start of COVID-19 symptoms **and** satisfy [criteria](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/hcp/disposition-in-home-patients.html) to discontinue isolation before getting the COVID-19 vaccine.
*   Wait 90 days to get the vaccine if you recovered from a COVID-19 infection and were treated with monoclonal antibodies or convalescent plasma.

More info: [Vaccines](https://covid19.ca.gov/vaccines/)

Question: Can I get a COVID-19 vaccine at the same time as another vaccine?
Answer:
The [CDC recommends](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/faq.html#):

*   Wait at least 14 days before getting any other vaccine, including a flu or shingles vaccine, if you get your COVID-19 vaccine first. And if you get another vaccine first, wait at least 14 days before getting your COVID-19 vaccine.
*   If a COVID-19 vaccine is inadvertently given within 14 days of another vaccine, you do not need to restart the COVID-19 vaccine series. You should still complete the series on schedule.

More info: [Vaccines](https://covid19.ca.gov/vaccines/)

Question: Is the COVID-19 vaccine safe for children?
Answer:
Currently, COVID-19 vaccines are not recommended for children:

*   Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine is for ages sixteen and above
*   Moderna vaccine is for ages eighteen and above
*   Johnson & Johnson vaccine is for ages eighteen and above

Clinical trials are ongoing to identify a safe vaccine for children.

More info: [Vaccines](https://covid19.ca.gov/vaccines/)

Question: Will I have a choice between the various COVID-19 vaccines?
Answer: It depends. Check with your health care provider about which vaccine they have available.\n\nMore info: [Vaccines](https://covid19.ca.gov/vaccines/)

Question: Are the COVID-19 vaccines mandatory?
Answer: No, there is no mandatory vaccination requirement from either the state or federal government.  Once more and more Californians see how safe and effective the COVID-19 vaccines are, we hope they will voluntarily opt to receive them.\n\nMore info: [Vaccines](https://covid19.ca.gov/vaccines/)

Question: Can an employer mandate vaccination at a workplace?
Answer:
Yes. An employer may require employees to receive FDA-approved vaccination against COVID-19 infection so long as the employer:

*   Does not discriminate against or harass employees or job applicants on the basis of protected characteristics
*   Provides reasonable accommodations related to disability or sincerely-held religious beliefs or practices
*   Does not retaliate against anyone for engaging in protected activities

Read more at DFEH’s [Employment information on COVID-19PDF (this is a pdf file)](https://www.dfeh.ca.gov/wp-content/uploads/sites/32/2020/03/DFEH-Employment-Information-on-COVID-19-FAQ_ENG.pdf).

More info: [Vaccines](https://covid19.ca.gov/vaccines/)

Question: How can I convince my family and friends to take a COVID-19 vaccine?
Answer:
Talking with family and friends about the benefits of getting a COVID-19 vaccine can be hard. You can help by listening without judgement and identifying the root of their concerns. Things to remember to help open the discussion include:

*   Listen to questions with empathy
*   Ask open-ended questions to explore concerns
*   Ask permission to share information
*   Help them find their own reason to get vaccinated
*   Help make their vaccination happen

The CDC has recommendations on [how to talk about COVID-19 vaccines with friends and family](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/talk-about-vaccines.html?ACSTrackingID=USCDC_2067-DM52837&ACSTrackingLabel=How%20to%20Talk%20to%20Family%20and%20Friends%20about%20COVID-19%20Vaccines%20%7C%20COVID-19&deliveryName=USCDC_2067-DM52837).

More info: [Vaccines](https://covid19.ca.gov/vaccines/)

Question: How is the state making vaccine decisions?
Answer:
A [group of experts](https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/Pages/COVID-19/Drafting-Guidelines-Workgroup.aspx/) and a [group of community representatives](https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/Pages/COVID-19/Community-Vaccine-Advisory-Committee.aspx/) work together to make sure vaccine distribution is prioritized fairly. 

California formed a [Scientific Safety Review Workgroup](https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/Pages/COVID-19/Scientific-Safety-Review-Workgroup.aspx) of experts to ensure the safety of COVID-19 vaccines. This workgroup has confirmed that the COVID-19 vaccines authorized by the FDA are safe and effective.

More info: [Vaccines](https://covid19.ca.gov/vaccines/)

Question: Who qualifies  for vaccination as Individuals at higher risk?
Answer:
### Individuals at higher risk

Vaccinations are available for the estimated 4.4 million people in California at higher risk for serious COVID-19 illness. This includes those with certain significant high-risk medical conditions, disabilities, illness, living spaces, or work environments.

Individuals with these conditions are strongly encouraged to check first with your usual health care provider. They can advise if you can get your vaccination with them, or in an alternate clinical setting.

**Health conditions**

Healthcare providers may use their clinical judgement to vaccinate individuals aged 16-64 who are [deemed to be at highest risk](https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/Pages/COVID-19/Provider-Bulletin-2-12-21.aspx) to get very sick from COVID-19 due to the following severe health conditions:

*   **Cancer**, current with weakened immune system
*   **Chronic kidney disease**, stage 4 or above
*   **Chronic pulmonary disease,** oxygen dependent
*   **Down syndrome**
*   **Solid organ transplant,** leading to a weakened immune system
*   **Pregnancy**
*   **Sickle cell disease**
*   **Heart conditions**, such as heart failure, coronary artery disease, or cardiomyopathies (but not hypertension)
*   **Severe obesity** (Body Mass Index ≥ 40 kg/m2)
*   **Type 2 diabetes mellitus** with hemoglobin A1c level greater than 7.5%

**Disabilities or illness**

Healthcare providers may also vaccinate individuals with  developmental or other severe disabilities or illness if:

*   The individual is likely to develop severe life-threatening illness or death from COVID-19 infection
*   Acquiring COVID-19 will limit the individual’s ability to get ongoing care or services vital to their well-being and survival
